entry.title: Lean and DRY CSS using Sass
entry.content:
I recently attempting to recreate a bare-bones Bootstrap-like grid system for a project and started delving a little deeper into the compilation process behind Sass. It’s easy enough to create a DRY Sass codebase but a bit more difficult to ensure that it translates into a DRY (and therefore smaller) CSS file. Using the right combination of mixins, placeholders and @extend can help here.

Mixins

Mixins are a primary feature of CSS preprocessors and an indispensable asset for creating a DRY codebase. They allow you to avoid using non-semantic tags like .align-left. They are function-like in that they can accept variables, process them, and return new data. They technically don’t return a value, but rather they dump CSS content into place.

Declaration example

The above example illustrates a square mixin that takes a $dimension parameter and injects two properties: width and height. You can assign a default value (in this case we’re using 100%.) The default value is used if no argument is supplied at the time the mixin is used.

Usage example
Compiled CSS

Placeholders

Placeholders are very similar to mixins. They also provide the capability to inject chunks of CSS into your code. The main difference is you can’t pass variables to placeholders. You would not be able to create the same functionality as the square mixin above with placeholders.

Declaration example:
Usage example

So, why would we bother using placeholders when we could just define a mixin with no parameters? The answer lies in the @extend function and the resulting compilation process. Placeholders are more efficiently compiled. Since they are not dependent upon context-specific variables, our preprocessor can optimize our final CSS code and avoid repetition. See below:

Compiled CSS

If we use a mixin for =vertical-align instead, we would get this:

Always choose to define a set of properties as a placeholder when they stay the same regardless of the context in which they are used. If you need to pass in variables that vary depending on the context, use a mixin.

@Extend

We used @extend in our example above. This is actually how we are avoiding the code from duplicating in the compiled stylesheet. @extend can be used to include static, reusable properties somewhere else in code. In our case this happens to be a placeholder. @extend can also be used on classes to DRY out our code.

As an example, we can create a button class. We want to create two alternate versions of our button class. We want both sub-classes to share the properties of the button class but also add their own. Also, we want to do this in the most efficient way possible without duplicating code in the processed stylesheet. Our two classes will be button-rounded (a button with rounded corners) and button-shadowed (a button with a box shadow.) We could nest the properties like so:

But, every time we want to create a button-rounded element, we’d have to assign it two classes: button and button-rounded. A better option would be to extend the button class into the alternate buttons like so:

Compiled:

Ahh, that’s better. We can now use .button, .button-rounded, or .button-shadowed individually. The compiled CSS has been optimized to group selectors with the same properties, resulting in a smaller stylesheet.

How do we know whether we should be extending .classes vs. %placeholders? %placeholders are like sass variables in the respect that they are not explicitly included in the final stylesheet. If we assign a variable in our Sass but don’t use it anywhere, you will not find it in the post-processed CSS. The same goes for placeholders. So, we should @extend classes when we are using the class on it’s own somewhere. In our button example, we are planning to apply the plain .button class to an element somewhere in our markup. If we were only planning on using .button-rounded and .button-shadowed in our markup but not actually the plain .button class anywhere, we would have defined button as a %placeholder instead.

Conclusion

Always use @extend with a .class or %placeholder if we want to duplicate non-dynamic properties. This will result in a lighter post-processed CSS stylesheet. @extend classes if the extensible class will be used on its own, otherwise use a %placeholder.

Mixins are duplicated in processed CSS and should be used only when necessary. When are they necessary? They are necessary only when we need to pass in a variable as an argument.

entry.title: Decimal, Binary, and Hexadecimal
entry.content:
Lately, I’ve been reading through some materials overviewing number systems, specifically in regards to computing. I’m going to jot down some of the reviewed ideas here.

The Decimal System

We’re all familiar with our Base 10 or decimal number system. It’s the most common number system globally and has been for quite some time. Evidence points to the first recorded usages of it in Egyptian Hieroglyphics dating back to ~3000 BC. Why 10? Probably because people tend to count using their fingers.

The idea behind the decimal system is simple. There are 10 symbols to work with:

Combined together, they can represent any quantity.

How do we represent quantity in a decimal system?

At a ridiculously simplified level, every number Base n number system works in a similar fashion. You count up using your available symbols 0.. 1.. 2.. (etc.) until you run out. When there are no more symbols left, a digit needs to be added. In order to get from 9 to 10, we flip the first (rightmost) digit back to our first symbol 0 and increase the newly added digit to the left 1 to leave us with 10.

In a Base 10 system, each digit represents a power of 10 (our base.) We count up in powers starting from the first (rightmost) digit.

The formula to convert any base number to decimal could be represented like this:

d is our digit

p is our position of our digit in the number starting from the first/rightmost (0)

B is our base

Lets try and apply this formula to a base 10 101.

… and one more time in Javascript

Binary

Modern computing is built upon the Base 2 or binary system. In binary we are limited to 2 symbols [0, 1]. In a binary system, 101 would convert to:

Why do we use Binary in Computer Science?

Transistors are basic building blocks of microchips. They are tiny switches that enable or disable the flow of electricity by connecting or disconnecting two ends of wire. Learn more about them here. There are some lower-level details about this that we won’t delve into here but ultimately, these signal-triggered switches allow for very basic binary calculations. When combined together, these binary calculations can represent more complex chunks of data. If we wanted to represent 1,234 in binary, we would get 10011010010. Adding a layer of abstraction on top of this, we could represent an alphabet in binary:

The fundamental unit of memory inside a computer is called a bit (short for “binary digit.) These are the switches we just mentioned. Group together 8 bits in a row and you have a byte. A byte is considered the “smallest operable unit of information” in computer storage and processing. We’re all familiar with seeing bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, gigabytes, terabytes, etc. to measure computer hardware metics like hard drive capacity and RAM. Generally speaking, bits are not used as units of measurement unless we’re focusing on data transfer speed or networking. For instance, your internet speed is probably defined in terms of bits/second. (kbps = kilobits/second while kBps = kilobytes/second)

A byte can represent any decimal number from 0 to 255. Why is this? Well, if we apply our formula above to a byte we can prove this. Knowing that we have a maximum of 8 potential bits/digits and the max symbol in a binary system on each of these digits would be 1, we can convert 1111 1111 to decimal. Plug this into the formula above and you’ll see we get 255.

255 is found throughout computer science as a maximum value. The American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) is a standard which assigns letters, numbers, and characters to the 256 slots available in a byte (well, the extended version does.) Colors are represented as ranges of 0-255 of red green, and blue.

Hexadecimal

Hexadecimal notation or Base 16 is commonly found throughout computer science. The notation employs 16 symbols

Hexadecimal numbers can represent larger quantities in smaller strings than base 10 since we have a larger set of symbols to work through before having to move up a column.

Why hex and not decimal? The answer is convenience. Computers are built upon bytes but us humans have an easier time reading/remembering 1D rather than 0001 1101. You may be asking yourself, “Why can’t we just use decimal then?” Hex is easily convertible back to binary. Each hex digit directly maps to 4 binary bits. There is no direct mapping available between decimal numbers and groups of 4 or 8 bits.

Some Examples of Hexadecimal in Computing

Basic Encoding

Hexadecimal representations are often represented in C and UNIX along with many of their successors using the prefix 0x. Try opening your inspector window and typing 0x5A3. It will output 1443, a decimal conversion of hexadecimal 5A3.

Colors

HTML colors can be represented using hexadecimal systems. Colors in HTML use an additive color system, a mix of varying amounts of red, green, and blue. We can have a combination of these three primary colors that range of intensities from 0 (least intense) - 255 (most intense.) As we stated before, 255 is the maximum number a byte can store.

rgb(0, 0, 0) would be the darkest or least intense combination of the 3 primary colors (black) or #000000 (hex). rgb(255,255,255) is the lightest (white) or most intense. White can also be represented by #FFFFFF (hex).

Unicode

Unicode, which is a superset of ASCII, representings a euro sign would as 20AC. Try typing ’\u20ac’ into your inspector window. \u is a unicode escape character.

URL Encoding

Hex is also implemented in URL encoding. Try typing this in your browser navigation bar: http:google.com/these are spaces. The browser will convert the spaces to their UTF-8 value (32) and then to hexadecimal (20) and prefix them with the % that indicates a special character encoding. You should get http:google.com/these%20are%20spaces.

entry.title: Unix Pipes vs. Redirects
entry.content:
These commands come in handy on a daily basis. At first, I ran into issues differentiating the two. I’ve documented some extra-simple examples of using both below.

Redirection >

Bash interprets the symbols > and >> as instructions to reroute a command’s input or output to or from a file.
> is used to pass output to either a file or stream.
The variation >> is used to append output to the end of a file
Note: we can also use < to redirect in the alternate direction.

Here’s an example:

The first command takes the standard output from the echo command (in this case: “testing testing 123”) and points it to test.txt, overwriting any content that was currently in this file if the file currently exists or creating a new file consisting of this standard output.

The second command takes the standard output from the echo command (in this case: “testing testing 456”) and appends it (note the double >>) to our test.txt file.

Our file will now look like this:

Pipes |

To connect the standard output of one command to the standard input of another use the | symbol, commonly known as a pipe. Pipes are used to pass output to another program or utility. So, if we’re trying to connect the i/o of a command to another command, we’ll use the |. But, if we want to take the output from a command and write it to a file or stream, we’ll use a redirect > or >>.

Here’s how a | would work on our test.txt file:

This will read the newly altered test.txt and output the content. Instead of printing the output to the screen (like it would have done with cat test.txt), the output will be “piped” to the grep process input. Here we can see that grep accepts standard input if no files are specified as arguments (which we have not, we’ve only specified the pattern 123.) The grep command will now search for 123 inside of the input that we’ve passed to it (which is the entire test.txt file) and will output the line:

testing testing 123

entry.title: The Rise of NoSQL
entry.content:
Below, I’m going to attempt to sum up some of the points Martin Fowler made in his Introduction to NoSQL talk at the GOTO Aarhus Conference 2012, mostly to hammer these concepts into my own forgetful brain. Fowler, who started developing software in the 80s, has written several notable books on topics including, but not limited to refactoring, application architecture, and NoSQL. Here is a link to the talk.

Problems with SQL

One of the central problems with relational databases is the “Object-Relational Impedance Mismatch.” Simply put, there is a gap between object-oritented design principles and databases. It’s difficult to map objects to databases. We can have a logical, cohesive user interface that makes perfect sense to the human eye, but when we try and store all this data, we are forced to split it up into a bunch of different tables linked together by relations.

Wouldn’t it be so much simpler to take the object and just drop it directly into the database? In the mid-90s, some smart people attempted to push the idea of Object Oriented Databases that would do just this. Unfortunately, the databases in place were overwhelmingly relational and the integration process ultimately prevented the OO databases from ever gaining significant traction. So instead of a complete paradigm shift, developers formed abstraction layers between relational databases and OO code bases called Object Relational Models. With these, large corporations that had invested heavily in storing their data in a relational way did not have to pay the high costs of migration from one database type to another. Developers could code their OO apps and companies didn’t have to mess with their data stores. Everyone was happy-ish.

What Changed?

As the early 2000s rolled around and the internet rose to prominence, software engineers faced a new set of challenges. Thousands of people were accessing websites simultaneously and developers scrambled to allow levels of scalability within their websites that could handle the traffic. One option was to increase their server size. Just buy a bigger box. SQL was designed for this. But this was expensive and provided provided room for a relatively small number of failure points, so companies like Google and Amazon began experimenting with alternate solutions. How about buying a bunch of little boxes instead and spreading all this data out? Fowler mentioned that engineers whom he spoke with who had tried making relational databases work across this type of distributed system often described the process using the phrase: “unnatural acts.” Ultimately, this led to the advent of the NoSQL databases.

NoSQL is a term that was coined as a Twitter hashtag for an early conference focused on such languages. It eventually just stuck. Fowler describes a set of common characteristics of NoSQL databases:

  • Non-relational
  • Open Source
  • Cluster-friendly
  • Works with 21st century website environments
  • No Set Schema

Data Model

When he says “no set schema,” he clarifies that there still ends up being an implicit schema when queries are made. If a query is made for an order, it may expect an order number and price. This implies a schema exists. This implicit schema still needs to be managed.

Mongodb.com defines these as “dynamic schema.” In an agile development environment, it’s common to have to alter database schemas frequently as new features are added. “There’s also no way, using a relational database, to effectively address data that’s completely unstructured or unknown in advance.”

Benefits

Relational databases naturally scale vertically. They require a single server to grow as the data volume grows. NoSQL DBs are designed to scale horizontally, often by supporting auto-sharding, load balancing, and/or automatic replication. Data can be spread among many cheap servers without the application needing to be aware of what’s going on behind the scenes.

Aggregate Oriented

The aggregate in Fowler’s words is often the highest-level “object” we are manipulating. In a document-focused DB like MongoDB, the aggregate would be the document. It is a single unit that we move back and forth from database to application. There is a type of NoSQL database that is not aggregate-oriented (graph) but I’m not going to get into that here.

NoSQL and Consistency

Consistency is the idea that when multiple people are accessing and making changes to a database, the data will remain consistent. Customer A should not be able to make a change to Product A while Customer B makes a different change at the same time, effectually overwriting Customer A’s. NoSQL databases are arguably weaker in this area compared to their relational counterparts. They have often been described as “eventually consistent.”

Fowler talks about an “offline lock” system to be used in such cases. Each data record or aggregate gets a version stamp. When a user retrieves this record, they also receive the stamp. If the user manipulates it and attempts to post back to the db and there is a version mismatch, they’ll receive an error. The version mismatch would be caused by another user updating the same record prior.

This type of consistency is “logical consistency.” It applies whether the data is on one server or distributed across many. Sharding data, or taking a copy of the data and splitting into shards on several machines brings up logical consistency problems.

Replicating data, or copying the same piece of data across multiple machines brings up different problems. It’s advantageous in terms of performance, i.e. more nodes handling the same request and resilience, i.e. if one node goes down, other nodes keep going. But, what happens if two people are making a request on a distributed DB and the communication line between the replicated DBs goes down? We can deny both requests and tell the users, “Sorry, there’s been an error with the network.” In this case, we ensure we aren’t going to run into data consistency issues but are giving the user a bad experience. Or, we can accept both requests and leave it up to the business to deal with it later down the line. For example, two people book the same room because of this and the hotel eventually just moves one of them into an alternate room. So essentially it’s a choice between consistency (1st option) and availability/response time, the latter of which says “Yes, I’ll keep going at the risk of introducing inconsistent data.” The more consistency you want, the more nodes have to communicate which can lead to a more expensive and slower operation. Fowler argues that this decision should ultimately be left up to the business.

When and why you’d want to use NoSQL

  • You’ve got to deal with large amounts of data.
  • You want to develop quickly.
  • You need to deal with analytics, i.e. pulling data from a wide variety of sources (excel, log files) with different structures.

Is NoSQL the future?

Fowler believes the future lies in “polyglot persistence.” He thinks there will be room for many different types of DBs and it will be up to the developer to determine which is appropriate for the problem at hand.

entry.title: Javascript Type Conversion
entry.content:
JavaScript’s automatic type conversion or type coersion can be tricky. When a statement expects a value of a certain type and the expression passed to it does not return one of that type, JavaScript will attempt to convert the given expression into the type it is looking for.

Usually, this is helpful, but sometimes it can lead to unexpected results. For example, the + operator will always concatenate values if one is a string, otherwise it will add two values together. In the example below, the number 1 is converted to a string.

But, the - operator will trigger a type conversion when applied to a string or strings, attempting to convert them to numeric values.

true converts to 1 when expected in an arithmetic operation and null converts to 0

Logical operators (|| or &&) work on all types. They expect boolean values though, so when presented with a non-boolean, they will convert it. If it converts to true, they return the original value. For this reason, logical operators are extremely useful in allowing for fallback values and null checks.

The below code is an example of ‘short-circuiting’ an evaluation. Since a is null, we fall back to the secondary value. But, if a had evaluated to true, then the second expression would never be evaluated.

Below, we are using the logical operator to perform a null check on a value we receieved for an imaginary API. If we tried to access c.inner.inner without the null check and c or c.inner did not exist, we would get a "Cannot read property 'inner' of undefined error." But, since we performed the check, the worst that can happen is the if conditional returns false and the program moves right along.

== checks for equality regardless of the type. Type conversion is performed here.

=== checks for equality and matching type. It actually runs faster since we are avoiding a type conversion here. This should be used when possible.

entry.title: Big O and Time Complexity
entry.content:
O(f(x)) is a mathematical term. “O” means order, as in “order of complexity” and big means… big (“O” not “o”.)

Big O notation allows us to analyze algorithms in an abstract fashion. It falls under the umbrella of complexity analysis. Most programming languages have a set of tools (such as profilers) that can measure the time it takes to run a particular chunk of code down to the millisecond. Big O is, by definition, a measure of our algorithm’s total number of machine calculations as we increase the input value towards infinity. It excludes coefficients and lower order terms. It is not a way to determine the exact time a process will take to complete in a certain language, but rather a higher level measurement of how complex an algorithm is.

Simply put:

Complexity analysis explains how an algorithm will behave as it’s input grows

We’re interested in our algorithm’s behavior as n tends towards infinity. The way we analyze this in computer science differs from how one would formally analyze O(f(x)) in mathematics. In mathematics we would include coefficients, constants, and lower order terms. For example:

Is filtered down in comp sci Big O notation to

f(n) = n

The idea behind this is that we want to isolate the parts of the function that will be effected by the growth of n. If we change n, does the constant 408 change? No. If we change n, does 10n behave differently than 20n would? No, not really. 20n would increase at the same linear rate as 10n, so overall, it’s behavior is the same. So we filter it down to a very basic level and say the function will change at a linear rate: f(n) = n which is expressed in Big O notation as O(n)

Another filter that is applied here by computer scientists and not mathematicians is to drop the terms that grow slowly and keep those that grow quickly as n increases. If we have a function f(n) = n<sup>2</sup> + 10n + 408, we will drop the constant and remove the multiplier 10 as we did before. But, we will also remove n from the leftover f(n) = n<sup>2</sup> + n since n will grow at a negligible rate compared to n2. What we are left with is f(n) = n<sup>2</sup>.

Some examples of common Big O time complexity are:

O(1) - Constant Time

Total number of calculations stays the same no matter how large or small our input is

O(n) - Linear Time
Total number of calculations grows linearly in relation to the input

O(n2) - Quadratic Time
Time execution is proportional to the square of the input size
